docs.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court split along ideological lines in ruling that state workers may not sue their employers for violations of part of the act, prompting the term’s first dissent read from the bench.

headline.seo: Supreme Court Rules on Family Leave Act Suits
headline.main: Justices Limit Suits Filed Over Family Leave Act Violations

docs.abstract: Supreme Court, by 5-to-4 vote split along ideological lines, rules that state workers may not sue their employers for violations of part of the federal Family and Medical Leave Act; decision prompts the term's first dissent read from the bench.

docs.lead_paragraph: In a study, women who gave birth to full-term small babies raced a greater risk of cardiovascular disease later in life.

headline.seo: Having Small Baby May Raise Mother’s Heart Risks
headline.main: Childbirth: Small Babies May Weaken Mothers’ Hearts
headline.print_headline: Childbirth: Small Babies May Weaken Mothers’ Hearts

docs.abstract: Dr Radek Bukowski study in journal PLoS One finds that a full-term pregnancy with a small baby may cause changes in a woman’s cardiovascular system that increase her risk for heart disease later in life.
docs.snippet: In a study, women who gave birth to full-term small babies raced a greater risk of cardiovascular disease later in life.

docs.lead_paragraph: For nearly three generations, women have been taught that annual Pap smears, mammograms and visits with their doctor were essential to good health. Now all that is changing. National guidelines are urging less frequent screening for breast and cervical cancer. The declining use of menopause hormones means that older women no longer need to check in with their doctors to obtain annual refills. Women are delaying childbirth, and some birth control methods are effective for five years, giving women even less incentive to schedule a regular appointment.

headline.main: The Annual Appointment Loses Some Relevance

docs.abstract: Tara Parker-Pope Well column notes that many women are unsettled by shifting national guidelines urging less frequent screening for breast and cervical cancers; contends that while there is a scientific basis for the opinion that fewer tests will yield fewer false-positives, annual visits are still useful, enabling gynecologists to discuss important non-reproductive issues with their patients. Drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite declining ratings - to say nothing of declining civilization - and the pregnancy of a cast member, MTV isn't ready to say goodbye to ''Jersey Shore'' just yet. On Monday the cable channel announced that it had ordered a sixth season of the reality series that gave the world Michael Sorrentino (better known as the Situation) and Nicole Polizzi (a k a Snooki), who in turn will be giving the world a Snooki Jr. in the months to come. MTV has already announced ''Jersey Shore'' spinoffs featuring Paul DelVecchio (Pauly D) as well as Ms. Polizzi and Jennifer Farley (nom de shore JWoww), and ratings for the original series tumbled to fewer than 5 million viewers for some of the final episodes of Season 5. Even so, ''Jersey Shore'' remains one of MTV's - and basic cable's - most popular shows with younger viewers.

headline.main: The Endless Summer: 'Jersey Shore' to Return

headline.main: An Accused Soldier's Family Life, Seen Through a Blog

docs.abstract: The wife of Staff Sgt. Robert Bales kept a blog, and her words should help remind us that when we deploy our troops, their families share their service, and their sacrifice.
docs.snippet: The wife of Staff Sgt. Robert Bales kept a blog, and her words should help remind us that when we deploy our troops, their families share their service, and their sacrifice.

docs.lead_paragraph: Staff Sgt. Robert Bales, accused of killing 16 Afghan civilians, was deployed four times in a decade to Iraq and Afghanistan.

headline.main: Suspect’s Multiple Tours Call Attention to War Strain
headline.print_headline: Suspect’s Tours Call Attention To War Strain

docs.abstract: Staff Sgt Robert Bales, soldier accused of killing 16 civilians in Afghanistan, was deployed four times to Iraq and Afghanistan over a decade, as he underwent stress from injuries, financial pressures, missed promotions and a wife going through pregnancy and single parenthood at home; narrative of mounting pressures is likely to be central to debate over what caused him to go on the rampage, but critics are quick to point out that many other soldiers endured similar difficulties.
docs.snippet: Staff Sgt. Robert Bales, accused of killing 16 Afghan civilians, was deployed four times in a decade to Iraq and Afghanistan.
